dialogue: How long before I die?
They quickly explained he wouldn’t die ... his body would make new blood.
He became everyone’s hero that night ... especially mine.
To cheer me up, Dad gave me Mum’s old jewellery box ...
... inside it had her snail collection and her ring ... She’d loved snails as well and had been a malacologist at the Melbourne Museum ...
... I thought Gilbert should have it.
I’m gonna wear this till the day I die, Gracie ...
Despite my woes, Sylvia ... I believed in glasses half full and silver linings.
Our home was our sanctuary ... especially my bedroom.
Right angles brought me enormous comfort ... as did my snails.
They were tangible memories of a mum I never met ... They were my friends ...
... so I made more of them ... I knew they’d never leave me ... hurt me ... or die.
I didn’t like people dying ... Suddenly he shifts his weight.
... I wanted to save people ... save the homeless ... my favourite was James.

One Christmas I covered him in decorations so he could feel some Christmas cheer. Grace looks happy and proud of herself. She takes some coins and teabags from her pocket and places them next to his drunken head.
He loved tea.
I wasn’t brave like Gilbert ... I retreated into my shell.

Despite his courage he was often sad ... seemed like he had a secret he wanted to tell ... His glass was half empty ... He was like Holden Caulfield, James Dean, and Charlie Brown all rolled into one.
He wanted to break free ...
... free others ...
Fly! ... FLY DAMN YOU! ... Go!
... rescue things.
Gilbert loved animals as well ... and even became a vegetarian.
We created our own little families.
You became my favourite, Sylvia ... your swirl went opposite to the others ...
Gilbert named you after Mum’s favourite author.
But the thing that made Gilbert really unique ... was his love of fire ... he wanted to eat it!
He’d spend hours playing with it ... inventing tricks ...
... he always smelt like burnt matches.
At school the girls swooned ... He was the flame ... they were the moths ...
... but he was more interested in his magic ... I think he just wanted to disappear ...
... and spend all his pocketmoney at Berts’s.
Bert was the type of person parents told you to avoid ... someone who might offer you boiled lollies.
Bert's seemed anything but magical. Flash forward twenty years to a fantasy scene of Gilbert as a handsome bohemian adult.
Gilbert’s dream was to be a street performer in Paris.
He was always practising ... and often burnt himself ...
... but pain didn’t bother him ... nor fear.
We got little scars and when we put our arms together ....
... they formed a face.
It felt great when we did this. Our feelings aligned ...
... A lot of twins say this Sylvia, and it’s true. I felt his emotions ... his happiness ...
... and his sadness ... which seemed to be the fourth member of our family.
Mum’s death had left a hole.
Dad had tried to fill the void ...
... but he had his own problems.
He was French and had once been a street performer and an animator in Paris ... he made stopmotion films with an old Bolex camera ... He showed them to us sometimes.
Mum met him on a holiday she’d won in the Woman’s Weekly Magazine.
Dear Gracie, my new parents Ruth and Owen are strange and do a weird sort of praying.
They make me pray four times a day. They said the more I pray the more the pain of Dad’s death will disappear ... ... You never get a mention!
They’re really old-fashioned and don’t even have a phone.
We all have to have magnets taped to us ... they reckon it keeps our auras balanced ... protects us from the devil.
Ruth is obsessed with her poor budgies. I reckon she loves them more than her own kids.
They’ve built their own church and school ... Owen is the Minister.
He’s got stomach ulcers ... which he blames on the devil.
My new brothers are all dickheads.
One of them is always staring.
I have to work in the orchard after school.
The brothers get the better jobs ... Ruth said if I’m gonna be a good Orchardman I’d have to start at the bottom and work my way up.
I’d rather eat glass ... Anyway, they can all get stuffed, coz as soon as I’m old enough and got money I’m comin to get you.
I’ll walk across that big burning desert ...
... we’ll escape to Paris. I’ll become a fire-eater ...
... and you’ll become an amazing animator.
... it’ll be great!
Gilbert gave me hope so I tried to get on with life ... squashing my sorrows down into my shoes as the months dragged ...
To pass time I began volunteering at the local library. One of my jobs was to erase lewd drawings made by juvenile delinquents.
That’s when I first met Pinky ... I saw her returning her books into a bin ... She thought it was the return chute and had been doing it for months.
Excuse me.
She was mortified when I explained ...
Yes ... I walked across that desert.
It took me a while to believe Gilbert was alive ... how he’d escaped the fire ...
... and how his ashes were nothing more, than ashes ...
We were finally free of our cages ... and even though our family had shrunk a little ...
... we were together again ...
... with only one thing left to release.
Gilbert still smelt like burnt matches ... The setting sun tingled our skin ...
... our two souls and single heart.
